item.author: Nimrod Kramer

item.title: Transparency
item.description:
I share everything I know with my team. Even when itâ€™s half-baked. Even when I have more questions than answers. Because the worst thing a founder can do is assume their team wonâ€™t understand or canâ€™t handle uncertainty. Thatâ€™s not leadership. Thatâ€™s insecurity.


People always see through the gaps. They notice the hesitation, the missing pieces, the unspoken doubts. Pretending otherwise doesnâ€™t protect anyone, it just erodes trust. And once trust is gone, good luck getting real alignment or urgency when you actually need it.


Transparency isnâ€™t just about honesty, itâ€™s about unlocking collective intelligence. When uncertainty is out in the open, it stops being paralyzing. It becomes a problem that multiple smart people can attack from different angles. Thatâ€™s how you move faster, not by waiting until everything is polished and â€œready.â€


Founders who keep information to themselves out of fear slow their own teams down. They create silos of doubt instead of a culture of action. Iâ€™d rather share the messy version early, because I trust my team to help make it better. And if you donâ€™t trust your people to handle reality, youâ€™ve probably already lost.
item.author: Nimrod Kramer

item.title: AI and stupidity, simplified
item.description:
There are 4 types of people:



  1. Smart + Driven

  2. Smart + Lazy

  3. Dumb + Lazy

  4. Dumb + Driven


AI is a force multiplier for everyone but when it supercharges the last group, it turns into a ticking time bomb for organizations.
item.author: Nimrod Kramer

item.title: Reputation points matter more than ever in 2025
item.description:
Starting in 2025, your reputation on daily.dev will directly impact your reach and visibility.


Until now, reputation has been a measure of trust and contributions in the community, unlocking key privileges along the way. But weâ€™re taking it a step further - higher reputation now increases the chances of your content being seen by more developers.


Whatâ€™s changing?



  • Posts from high-reputation users will get better chances to gain organic exposure on the feed.

  • Your contributions will be prioritized in ranking algorithms, potentially leading to higher engagement and reach.

  • Reputation now plays a bigger role in establishing credibility across the platform.


Why this matters


We want daily.dev to be a place where quality contributions rise to the top. By making reputation more influential, weâ€™re ensuring that the best insights, discussions, and knowledge get the attention they deserve.


Want to grow your reputation? Keep sharing valuable content, engaging in discussions, and contributing positively to the community.


Learn more about how reputation works here: https://docs.daily.dev/docs/your-profile/reputation
item.author: Nimrod Kramer

item.title: Advice
item.description:
Everyone has advice. Most of it is useless.


The second you start building something, people line up to tell you what to do. How to run your company. How to lead your team. How to raise money.


Hereâ€™s the problem. Most of these people have no idea what theyâ€™re talking about.


They havenâ€™t built anything. Theyâ€™ve never hired a team. Theyâ€™ve never stared down a runway thatâ€™s running out. But theyâ€™ll still tell you how to scale, how to focus, or how to lead.


Itâ€™s easy to give advice when you have nothing to lose. No skin in the game.


The truth is, most advice will slow you down.


Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned about listening to â€œadviceâ€:



  • If it sounds like a LinkedIn post or a self-help book, ignore it.

  • If theyâ€™re more focused on sounding smart than being helpful, ignore it.

  • If theyâ€™ve never been where you are, ignore them. There are exceptions, but thatâ€™s for another post.


Good advice comes from people whoâ€™ve been through the fire. People who get the hard calls youâ€™re making. People who respect that youâ€™re the one actually doing the work.


Good advice comes from those who know their zone of genius and stay in it.


Good advice comes from those with skin in the game.


The rest? Let them talk. Youâ€™ve got work to do.
